message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or another autoimmune disease. Anti-double stranded DNA (dsDNA) antibodies are the most specific test for confirming a diagnosis of SLE. Anti-histone antibodies are seen in drug-induced lupus and not specific to SLE. Anti-topoisomerase (anti-Scl 70) antibodies are seen in systemic sclerosis, and anti-Ro antibodies are seen in Sjogren's syndrome and neonatal lupus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest an autoimmune disorder, specifically systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The most specific test to confirm the diagnosis of SLE is the anti-double stranded DNA (dsDNA) antibodies test. The other options are associated with other autoimmune disorders like drug-induced lupus, scleroderma, and Sjogren's syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the pink rash on the nose and cheekbones, suggest systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Anti-double stranded DNA (dsDNA) antibodies are the most specific for confirming the diagnosis of SLE. The other options are associated with other autoimmune diseases but are not specific for SLE.

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are the most specific for confirming the diagnosis of SLE. Anti-histone antibodies are found in drug-induced lupus. Anti-topoisomerase antibodies are associated with scleroderma. Anti-Ro antibodies are found in Sjogren’s syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Anti-double stranded DNA (dsDNA) antibodies are most specific for confirming the diagnosis of SLE. Anti-histone antibodies are associated with drug-induced lupus, anti-topoisomerase (anti-Scl 70) antibodies are specific for scleroderma, and anti-Ro antibodies are associated with Sjögren's syndrome but can also be seen in other autoimmune diseases.

Anti-double stranded DNA (dsDNA) antibodies have high specificity for SLE and are often used to confirm the diagnosis. The other options are associated with other autoimmune disorders.
